Language Switching from Multiple Perspectives |date=2003 |publisher=John Benjamins Publishing |isbn=978-90-272-4891-6 |pages=233–251 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W1h9oF9rj-MC&pg=PA233 |access-date=August 4, 2020 }} Cheaper Tagalog tabloids, which feature crime, sex, gossips and gore, saw a rise in the 1990s, and tend to be popular among the masses, particularly in Manila.{{cite book |last1=Kusaka |first1=Wataru |title=Moral Politics in the Philippines: Inequality, Democracy and the Urban Poor |date=2017 |publisher=NUS Press |isbn=978-981-4722-38-4 |pages=63–65 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hb7WDgAAQBAJ&pg=PA63 |access-date=August 4, 2020 }}{{cite news |last1=Whaley |first1=Floyd |title=Manila's Gory, Sexy Tabloids Outsell Traditional Broadsheets |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/27/world/asia/manilas-gory-sexy-tabloids-outsell-traditional-newspapers.html |access-date=August 4, 2020 |work=The New York Times |date=June 26, 2012}} === Cuisine === {{Main|Filipino cuisine}} Regional variations exist throughout the islands, for example [[rice]] is a standard starch in Luzon while [[cassava]] is more common in Mindanao.{{Cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=y6vTun3i4NQC&pg=PA266 |title = The Ethnic Food Lover's Companion: Understanding the Cuisines of the World |author = Zibart, Eve |publisher = Menasha Ridge Press |year = 2001 |pages = 268, 277 |isbn = 978-0-89732-372-7}} Filipino taste buds tend to favor robust flavors, but the cuisine is not as spicy as those of its neighbors.{{Cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=PEy9G-HLokwC&pg=PA281 |title = Authentic Though not Exotic: Essays on Filipino Identity |author = Zialcita, Fernando Nakpil |publisher = Ateneo de Manila University Press |location = Quezon City |year = 2005 |page = 281 |isbn = 978-971-550-479-9}}{{failed verification|date=July 2020}} Unlike many Asians, most Filipinos do not eat with [[chopsticks]]; they use Western cutlery. However, possibly due to rice being the primary staple food and the popularity of a large number of stews and main dishes with broth in Filipino cuisine, the main pairing of utensils seen at the Filipino dining table is that of [[spoon]] and [[fork]], not knife and fork.{{Cite book|url = https://archive.org/details/isbn_9781741042894 |url-access = registration |quote = filipino cuisine. |title = Philippines |author1 = Rowthorn, Chris |author2 = Greg Bloom |name-list-style = amp |edition = 9th |publisher =Lonely Planet|year = 2006 |page = [https://archive.org/details/isbn_9781741042894/page/48 48] |isbn = 978-1-74104-289-4}} The traditional way of eating with the hands known as ''kamayan'' (using the hand for bringing food to the mouth){{cite web | last =Lowry | first =Dave | title =Hand-to-Mouth Combat: Experiencing a Kamayan Dinner at Hiro Asian Kitchen | url=https://www.stlmag.com/dining/hand-to-mouth-combat-experiencing-a-kamayan-dinner-at-hiro-asian-kitchen/ | date=January 6, 2016}} was previously more often seen in the less urbanized areas. However, due to the various Filipino restaurants that introduced Filipino food to people of other nationalities, as well as to Filipino urbanites, ''kamayan'' fast became popular.{{cite book |last1=Barrios |first1=Joi |title=Tagalog for Beginners: An Introduction to Filipino, the National Language of the Philippines (Downloadable MP3 Audio Included) |date=July 15, 2014 |publisher=Tuttle Publishing |isbn=978-1-4629-1039-7 |page=397 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DxA9BAAAQBAJ&pg=PT397 |access-date=September 3, 2020 }}{{cite book |last1=Alejandro |first1=Reynaldo G. |title=Authentic Recipes from the Philippines |date=March 13, 2012 |publisher=Tuttle Publishing |isbn=978-1-4629-0533-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IzXRAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT35 Philippines.{{cite book|last1=Cho|first1=Younghan|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DYz7CwAAQBAJ&pg=PA87|title=Modern Sports in Asia|last2=Leary|first2=Charles|date=2016|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-317-58638-8|page=87|access-date=July 27, 2020}} In 2010, [[Manny Pacquiao]] was named [[Edward J. Neil Trophy#2000s|"Fighter of the Decade"]] for the 2000s by the [[Boxing Writers Association of America]].{{cite news|last=Himmer|first=Alastair|date=June 5, 2010|title=Pacquiao named fighter of the Mano|Arnis]].{{cite web|title=An Act Declaring Arnis as the National Martial Art and Sport of the Philippines|url=https://lawphil.net/statutes/repacts/ra2009/ra_9850_2009.html|access-date=July 25, as a pastime in the kingdom of Taytay.{{cite book|last=Dundes|first=Alan|title=The Cockfight: A Casebook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wy5VqKSYt8IC|year=1994|publisher=Univ of Wisconsin
